articleContentTranslated: In the finish, after radio problems, Mercedes erroneously fitted the front tires intended for team-mate Valtteri Bottas on the car of the leading Russell. Wolff also provided an explanation. â€œThe right side didn't hear the radio message.
And so the wrong tire was out for the wrong car. That shouldn't happen, but it also happens to our team. And that shows that people are at work. "

Because this faux pas was immediately corrected by further pit stops by both drivers, the team was left with a fine of 20,000 euros. Under normal circumstances, Russell would have threatened a penalty up to disqualification.

But it was the first time that a rule break had occurred in this form, it was said in the grounds of the judgment of the racing stewarts. Chaos in the Mercedes box With a huge mistake when changing tires, the Mercedes mechanics probably gave away a double victory for the silver file.

The devil is in the details The trigger for the blackout when changing tires was that the Russell team could not understand the information over the radio that their driver was about to pit before Bottas because the driver himself was talking on the radio.

The radio problem is due to the fact that the messages are being prioritized, explained Mercedes engineer Andrew Shovlin. "When the safety car drove onto the track, we asked the crew to prepare and bring the tires for both cars into the pit lane," said the Briton.

"As this message was just being sent, another radio message for a very brief moment prevented any of the important messages from getting through to some of the guys picking up the tires," said Shovlin.

"Small mistake has changed everything" The Stewarts justified their judgment because of the further course of action at Mercedes. "One little mistake changed everything today," said the deprived Russell.
The 22-year-old Williams pilot had come into the team instead of the seven-time world champion Hamilton, who had Covid-19, and would have won immediately without the bad luck.

Mercedes does not rule out a deployment of Hamilton for the season finale. "If it is free of Covid-19 and receives the green light, then it will drive," said Wolff.

Hamilton tested positive for the corona virus twice last Monday and had to go into quarantine in Bahrain. His team confirmed mild symptoms in the 35-year-old. Wolff said that the Briton had to stay in bed and that he was not feeling well.

It is therefore unclear whether the Briton can present a negative coronavirus test in time. The teams are expected to have to register their drivers for the Grand Prix in Abu Dhabi by Tuesday. "If he can't be there, George drives," said Wolf.
